OFFICE FOR RESEARCH PROTECTIONS
THE 330 BUILDING SUITE 205
UNIVERSITY PARK, PA 16802

citations.narrative:
There were 2 incidents involving improper handling of red-backed voles. On May 22, 2023, an animal caretaker was using
a plastic tube to transfer between cages when the vole leapt from the tube and fell on the floor. The animal was
recaptured in a plastic cup but died shortly afterwards. Necropsy results did not show obvious signs of trauma but there
was reportedly some stress involved in the recapture. On February 1, 2024, a red-backed vole jumped out the cage when
the caretaker opened the lid to provide extra food. The animal jumped from both the primary and secondary containers
landing on the floor. The animal was recaptured in a net but died shortly afterwards. Necropsy results were consistent
with injury from a fall to the floor.
Failure to handle animals in a careful manner can lead to trauma including death.
Handling of all animals must be done as carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, behavioral stress,
physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.
Correct by: February 28, 2024

There were 2 instances in which animals were missing from their housing facility and never recovered. A white-footed
mouse was discovered to be missing from its cage on January 23, 2023. Personnel searched the room and live traps
were set but the mouse was not recovered. A meadow vole also went missing between 12/29/23 and 1/4/24.
Failure of housing facilities to contain the animals can result in escape and inability to recover the animals.
Housing facilities must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.
Corrective actions included training of personnel. Correct by continuing to ensure housing facilities contain the animals
from February 28, 2024 forward

There were 2 animals that were not provided with adequate water resulting in their death. Two red-backed voles were
found dead in their cage on January 12, 2023. The sipper tube of the water bottle was found to be improperly positioned
and not accessible to the animals. Necropsy results were consistent with lack of water as the cause of death.
Failure to provide water that is accessible to the animals can result in dehydration, and if prolonged, can result in death.
Potable water must be provided as often as necessary for the health and comfort of the animals.
Corrective actions included additional training of lab and animal care staff to review proper water bottle replacement.
Correct by continuing to provide adequate water to all animals from February 28, 2024 forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the IACUC representatives.
n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
There were 2 incidents involving improper handling of red-backed voles. On May 22, 2023, an animal caretaker was using 
a plastic tube to transfer between cages when the vole leapt from the tube and fell on the floor. The animal was 
recaptured in a plastic cup but died shortly afterwards. Necropsy results did not show obvious signs of trauma but there 
was reportedly some stress involved in the recapture. On February 1, 2024, a red-backed vole jumped out the cage when 
the caretaker opened the lid to provide extra food. The animal jumped from both the primary and secondary containers 
landing on the floor. The animal was recaptured in a net but died shortly afterwards. Necropsy results were consistent 
with injury from a fall to the floor. 
Failure to handle animals in a careful manner can lead to trauma including death. 
Handling of all animals must be done as carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, behavioral stress, 
physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. 
Correct by: February 28, 2024 
3.125(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
There were 2 instances in which animals were missing from their housing facility and never recovered. A white-footed 
mouse was discovered to be missing from its cage on January 23, 2023. Personnel searched the room and live traps 
were set but the mouse was not recovered. A meadow vole also went missing between 12/29/23 and 1/4/24. 
Failure of housing facilities to contain the animals can result in escape and inability to recover the animals. 
Housing facilities must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
Corrective actions included training of personnel. Correct by continuing to ensure housing facilities contain the animals 
from February 28, 2024 forward 
3.130  Critical
   
Watering. 
There were 2 animals that were not provided with adequate water resulting in their death. Two red-backed voles were 
found dead in their cage on January 12, 2023. The sipper tube of the water bottle was found to be improperly positioned 
and not accessible to the animals. Necropsy results were consistent with lack of water as the cause of death. 
Failure to provide water that is accessible to the animals can result in dehydration, and if prolonged, can result in death.

Potable water must be provided as often as necessary for the health and comfort of the animals. 
Corrective actions included additional training of lab and animal care staff to review proper water bottle replacement. 
Correct by continuing to provide adequate water to all animals from February 28, 2024 forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the IACUC representatives. 
 
 n
